org.springframework.cloud.config.java

Annotation Type ServiceScan


  • @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Target(value=TYPE)
 @Documented
 @Import(value=ServiceScanConfiguration.class)
public @interface ServiceScan
    Add this annotation to an @Configuration class to have the services bound to the app scanned and bean for each one added to the application context: 
     @Configuration
 @ServiceScan
 public class CloudConfiguration {
     // may (optionally) extend AbstractCloudConfiguration
 }
    This annotation is similar to @ComponentScan in Spring, which scans for classes with the @Component classes and creates a bean for each. @ServiceScan, in the same spirit, scans services bound to the app and creates a bean for each. Upon service scanning, if there is a unique bean for service type, you can inject it using the following code (shows Redis, but the same scheme works for all services): 
     @Autowired RedisConnectionFactory redisConnectionFactory;
    If there are more than one services of a type, you can use the @Qualifier annotation as in the following code: 
     @Autowired @Qualifier("service-name1") RedisConnectionFactory redisConnectionFactory;
 @Autowired @Qualifier("service-name2") RedisConnectionFactory redisConnectionFactory;
    Author:
    Ramnivas Laddad
